p: While previous starch studies in North China have focused on identifications at single sites, this study considers diachronic change in starch remains through the 20,000-year time period from the LGM to the Holocene Climatic Optimum. Our focus on cereals provides evidence of inter-related trajectories in the exploitation of Paniceae and Triticeae tribe members across five stages of human-plant interactions, from collecting wild cereals by mobile foragers to agricultural production.
